This effect is additive, e.g. if your army morale is 200%, this will raise it to 250%.

This effect is multiplicative. The max organization of a land unit is (base organization of unit + army organization from techs) * (1 + land organization). An infantry brigade has a base organization of 30, so without any techs researched the max org it will have with this modifier is (30 + 0) * (1 + 0.2) = 36.
This reduces supply consumption for all units by 10%.
This gives -15% Supply Consumption Bonus. For example, if the base supply consumption of your armies is increased to 200% from techs, this will lower it to 170%.

This bonus reduces POP deaths from combat casualties to a rate of 1 to 0.208, down from a base rate of 1 to 0.25. POP deaths from combat casualties is calculated as SOLDIER_TO_POP_DAMAGE/(1 + military_hospital modifier). The base SOLDIER_TO_POP_DAMAGE in this mod is 0.25, so a military hospital modifier of 20% or 0.2, reduces POP deaths to 0.25/(1 + 0.2) = 0.208.

This bonus reduces POP deaths from combat casualties to a rate of 1 to 0.208, down from a base rate of 1 to 0.25. POP deaths from combat casualties is calculated as SOLDIER_TO_POP_DAMAGE/(1 + military_hospital modifier). The base SOLDIER_TO_POP_DAMAGE in this mod is 0.25, so a military hospital modifier of 20% (0.2), reduces POP deaths to 0.25/(1 + 0.2) = 0.208.
Each point of experience lowers the damage taken during combat at the same rate as one point of military tactics.

This bonus increases reinforce rate by +10%. No matter the reinforce rate however, your units' reinforce rate is multiplied by the amount of supplies they are getting, so if your armies aren't getting any supplies they won't reinforce even with a large reinforce rate bonus.
Your units' reinforce rate is multiplied by the amount of supplies they are getting, so if your armies aren't getting any supplies they won't reinforce even with a large reinforce rate bonus.
Navy Build Speed National Idea\n§WNavies: Build Time §G-30%\n§WLocal Ship Repair Speed: §G+50%
Base build time of ships is reduced by 30% and repair is 50% faster. The base build time reduction stacks with base build time reductions from port levels and other techs.

This effect is multiplicative. The max organization of a naval unit is (base organization of unit + navy organization from techs) * (1 + navy organization). For example, a frigate has a base org of 30, and if it has +18 org from techs, the max org it will have with this modifier is (30 + 18) * (1 + 0.15) = 55.2.

Assimilation rate is multiplied by the assimilation chance to determine the amount of assimilation in a POP. If either assimilation rate or chance is 0, or there is no assimilation target, then no assimilation will take place. POPs will never assimilate in a province they have a core in, so e.g. Romanian POPs in Romanian cored land won't assimilate but Romanian POPs in non Romanian land will assimilate.
Provides an output bonus to various factory produced consumer goods.
Provides an output bonus to various factory produced industrial goods.

Unlocks Migration Attraction decision, which redirects incoming immigrants and internal migrants to the targetted province. This does NOT increase the amount of outside POPs that immigrate to your country.

column2: Universal healthcare is a health care system in which all residents of a particular country or region are assured access to health care. It is generally organized around providing either all residents or only those who cannot afford on their own with either health services or the means to acquire them, with the end goal of improving health outcomes.

Free public education is available to all and attendance is mandatory. Teachers are certified to a standardized curricula by either the government or a teachers' organisation. Higher education institutions are excellent and poor students are given subsidies by the government in order to attend.

Gives a large bonus to migration to the targeted province. This decision does not increase the chance of receiving immigrants from other countries, it only redirects them to the targetted province. If a province has more than 5% RGO unemployment then the modifier will stop working and should be reset.

Capital Supply Depot\n§WCapital Supply Depots will not be destroyed unless the capital is moved somewhere else.
We require time to procure new supplies before we can build another supply depot.
Appoint an Irish Lord-Lieutenant of Ireland

Lord Heytesbury, the current Lord-Lieutenant of Ireland, has been criticized for his inaction during the Irish Famine, believing it would resolve itself. This neglect has only worsened the crisis. We must appoint a new Irish Lord-Lieutenant who will take decisive action to prevent future disasters and bring in Irish support for the crown.

The Act of Union of 1800 denied the Irish proper representation in the UK government. It is time to rectify this injustice by granting the Irish seats in Parliament, ensuring their voices are heard and their interests represented.
We must integrate the Irish into our country.
@IRE §GThis is required to progress for Irish Acceptance.§b

Napoleon III (Charles Louis Napoléon Bonaparte 20 April 1808 – 9 January 1873) was the first President of France (as Louis-Napoléon Bonaparte) from 1848 to 1852 and Emperor of the French from 1852 to 1870. A nephew of Napoleon I, he was the last monarch to reign over France. Elected to the presidency of the Second Republic in 1848, he seized power by force in 1851, when he could not constitutionally be reelected he later proclaimed himself Emperor of the French. He founded the Second Empire, reigning until the defeat of the French Army and his capture by Prussia and its allies at the Battle of Sedan in 1870. Napoleon III was a popular monarch, who used plebiscites to guide his actions, oversaw the modernisation of the French economy and worked to have the centre of Paris rebuilt following Napoleon III style guidelines. He expanded the French overseas empire and made the French merchant navy the second largest in the world, engaged in the Crimean War, the Second Italian War of Independence, the Second Franco-Mexican War, as well as the disastrous Franco-Prussian War, in which he served alongside his soldiers during the fight, an uncommon action for a head of state in the modern era.

Napoleon wasn't the best, wasn't perfect, but he has led us for a good duration of time fighting against adversaries, and ensuring the French State would be strong enough to fight a united Germany/Prussia, now that hes gone, its best to preserve his reign and existance.

As Louis Napoleon grasped dictatorial power and introduced a harsh constitution he took the next step and held a referendum for the reintroduction of the Empire. Nearly 8 million Frenchmen voted yes and he became French Emperor under the name Napoleon III. \n§RBonapartiste is the required Party

While Germany was not united until the proclamation of the German Empire, following the Franco-Prussian war, rising nationalism in the 19th century had meant that unification had been on the cards long before that, with the Frankfurt assembly of 1848 being an important forerunner. By achieving a dominant position among the South German states, we can form the South German Confederation.

With our dominant position over the south German states, we can create the South German Confederation -- a union that would be under our full control, and a more useful ally than the nations separately.

In 1860, Queen Isabella II of Spain faced growing opposition due to her perceived political favoritism, corruption in the royal court, and failure to implement meaningful reforms. Her reign had become increasingly unstable, prompting liberal and progressive factions to advocate for her removal. Although she remained on the throne until 1868, by 1860, political discourse was already rife with discussions about alternative leadership.

Since the days of Charlemagne and the Holy Roman Empire, the French Crown has looked eastward to the Rhine as both a natural frontier and the heart of European power. The Revolutionary and Napoleonic Wars only deepened these ambitions, with French armies long having marched through and governed the Rhineland. Now, as the French Empire stands strong once more, voices in Paris call for the reassertion of our historical rights and influence over the Rhine. To secure these lands would be to ensure France?s natural border, safeguard our prestige, and remind Europe of our imperial destiny.
Revive Claims on the Dutch Lowlands

The Dutch Republic once stood as a rival to France, but from the days of Louis XIV to the Napoleonic Empire, French arms repeatedly crossed the Meuse and brought the Low Countries under Parisian influence. The Kingdom of the Netherlands is but a fragile construct of the Congress of Vienna, propped up as a barrier against French power. Yet many in the Tuileries whisper that the destiny of France is not complete until our tricolor once more flies over Amsterdam and the North Sea coast, securing the Rhine delta as a bulwark of French supremacy.

The Belgian Revolution tore away lands that France had long considered within her rightful sphere. From the days of the Revolution and Napoleon, Belgium was governed as French soil, its resources and fortresses guarding our northern frontier. The so-called ?Kingdom of Belgium? is little more than a British invention, a buffer state designed to restrain French power. By reclaiming Belgium, France restores her natural border along the Meuse and Scheldt, secures her northern flank, and reasserts her role as master of the Low Countries.

In the 17th century, Dutch merchants of the East India Company established Fort Zeelandia on the island of Formosa, creating a hub of commerce that linked China, Japan, and the Indies. Though this foothold was lost to native resistance and Ming loyalists, the dream of a Dutch Formosan trade port has never fully died. By reasserting our influence over Taiwan, we may once more command the sea lanes of East Asia, strengthen our colonial empire, and remind the world that the Netherlands remains a power of global reach.

The Cape of Good Hope was once the jewel of the Dutch East India Company, a vital resupply station linking Europe with Asia. Though Britain seized the colony during the Napoleonic Wars and has held it since, many in the Netherlands still see the Cape as rightfully Dutch. The Afrikaners who remain carry our language, our faith, and our traditions, a living testament to the legacy of the Republic overseas. By reasserting our claims upon South Africa, we may restore Dutch prestige abroad, reclaim a gateway to the East, and remind the world that the Oranje banner has not faded from the Cape.

In the modern age, commerce is power. The Portuguese and Spanish first opened the routes to Asia, but it was the Dutch and English who perfected the system of monopolized trade through chartered companies. These East India Companies became more than mere merchants ? they were states within states, armed with private armies, fleets, and the authority to rule colonies in the name of profit. By creating our own East India Company, we shall secure monopolies over spices, tea, and textiles, ensure the flow of wealth into our coffers, and extend our influence far beyond Europe?s shores. Such a charter will mark our nation as not merely a power at home, but a force in the world?s markets and empires.

The Carlist cause is more than a struggle for Spain?s throne ? it is a struggle for Spain?s soul. We are heirs to the legacy of Charles V and Philip II, to the empire on which the sun never set. The liberal governments have squandered this inheritance, abandoning our colonies and bowing before foreign powers. But a true monarch does not forget the Indies. The lands of New Spain, Peru, and beyond once recognized the authority of the Spanish Crown, and they may yet again. By reviving the dream of empire across the ocean, we proclaim that the Carlist throne is not only the rightful ruler of Spain, but the rightful lord of the New World.

Though Isabella II has been cast down from the throne, her shadow lingers over Spain. To republicans, she is the last relic of a corrupt monarchy, a reminder of the misrule and decadence that brought Spain to ruin. Yet to her dwindling supporters, she remains a figurehead ? a living symbol of the crown?s claim, however tarnished. The Republic must decide whether to tolerate her presence as a powerless exile or erase the last vestiges of Bourbon rule. Only then can Spain truly embrace its new republican destiny.
Gain support for a new leader
